title: rose dont be a thorn in natalies side
story: After all, her incredibly brave allegations of rape and sexual assault levelled at the then all-powerful Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein blazed the trail for the #MeToo movement that emerged in .And she has been a fearless activist ever since, pursuing justice and equality.But I’m afraid it was a dud move on her part to criticise actress Natalie Portman for her decision to walk the red carpet at Sunday night’s Oscars wearing a custom Dior gown and cape, which was adorned with the names of some of the female directors who weren’t nominated this year.In her own way, Natalie wanted to shine a lighton the fact that, for the ninth year in the past decade, all five of the best director nominees were male.The female directors highlighted on Natalie’s gown included Lorene Scafaria , Lulu Wang , Greta Gerwig , Marielle Hellerand Melina Matsoukas .Whatever you think about her way of doing it, there’s no doubt she made a point.And the fact that she was standing on the red carpet made it a more powerful point thanshe had, say, boycotted the event or stood outside with a placard.But in a social media post, Rose McGowan referred to ­Portman’s cape as: “The kind of protest that gets rave reviews from the mainstream media for its ­bravery.”“Brave ”, she wrote. “No, not by a long shot. More like an actress acting the part of someone who cares. As so many of them do.“I find Portman’s type of activism deeply offensive to those of us who actually do the work. I’m not writing this out of bitterness, I am writing out of disgust,” she wrote.Unfortunately, coming from someone who has been so integral in the protest movement, this sounds like sour grapes.Natalie’s response to Rose’s criticism was as elegant and as understated as her protest.She said: “I agree with Ms McGowan that it is inaccurate to call me ‘brave’ for wearing a garment with women’s names on it.“Brave is a term I more strongly associate with actions like those of the women who have been testying against Harvey Weinstein the last few weeks.”She also responded to Rose’s accusation that Natalie has only been directed twice by women.But in this criticism, Rose is seriously missing the point. Female directors don’t get as far in Hollywood as male ones, which is precisely what Natalie is pointing out with her cloak protest. Therefore, there are fewer available to work with.As Natalie said: “It is true I’ve only made a few films with women. In my long career, I’ve only gotten the chance to work with female directors a few times . . . Unfortunately, the unmade films I have tried to make are a ghost history.“Female films have been incredibly hard to get made at studios, or to get independently financed. If these films do get made, women face enormous challenges during the making of them.”By the way, this is not the first time Natalie has protested from within the system.While presenting the best director category at the Golden Globes in , she introduced the line-up by saying: “And here are the all-male nominees.”Again, it’s not a shouty, noisy street protest. But it served to make her point. Just that she did it in a dferent way than Rose might. And that’s fine.In fact, some people think that Rose’s in-your-face type of protest risks alienating some people.I think women should support each other when it comes to vying for equality.But also, Rose just sounded spiteful when she said Natalie was “an actress acting like someone who cares”.Rose is a hero to many women. But she needs to understand that whether their contribution is big or small, loud or subtle, anyone’s effort to affect change helps.JANE Fonda, who looked fabulous at the Oscars, has said she is done with plastic surgery.Well, I guess  is as good an age as any to stop nipping and tucking.She must have a great doctor, as whatever the actress has had done has been done very well indeed – because, in my experience, it’s not often you look better after a facelt than you did before.PERHAPS Andrea Leadsom had a premonition that she was going to be axed as Business Secretary in this week’s Cabinet reshuffle.She recently wrote a column obliquely warning Boris Johnson not to cut the number of female ministers in his Cabinet.Addressing the issue of female board members among FTSE  companies, Andrea wrote: “Working in the City in the Nineties, I saw myself how a male-dominated environment can limit a career.”Unfortunately for her, the warning did not save her skin and she has been sacked, along with Theresa Villiers as Environment Secretary and housing minister Esther McVey.By the way, eight of the  members of Mr Johnson’s first Cabinet were female –  per cent.Despite these sackings, that figure has actually risen – slightly – to nearly  per cent.Ideally, the split would be an even -.But the reality is that business and politics can both be brutal.Men and women alike must accept they might one day get the sack.It simply goes with the territory.Being selected on the basis of gender is just as wrong as being sacked on that basis.Right person, right job, regardless of their gender.THAT is what true equality means.SAY what you like about the bonkers lestyle advice dispensed by Gwyneth Paltrow on Goop – and some of it is seriously out there.But whatever she is doing clearly works.She is, at the age of , nothing short of radiant.In fact she looks amazing and also happy.Not only that but she became instantly relatable to parents everywhere with a confession that her -year- old daughter finds her embarrassing.That’s a good reminder there is nothing like a teenager to keep you normal and down to earth for fear that you will embarrass them, no matter what you do.Although, to be fair, perhaps Gwyneth’s daughter has had a predisposition to feel embarrassed by her mother ever since she named her  . . . Apple.What are the ethics of seat-reclining on a long-haul flight An American Airlines passenger raised the question after video-shaming a fellow traveller who punched and pushed her seat when she reclined it.Bearing in mind the recline button moves the seat about in, I suspect this chap has anger issues, as reclining a seat that has a recline button is hardly an act of aggression.I’d disable the recline button and then all you have to fight over is the armrest.DAMIAN Hurleys resemblance to his mother, Liz, is uncanny.More so than ever in the latest shots of the two of them together, which he posted online this week.Some people think it is vaguely unsettling that he looks more like Liz Hurley than Liz Hurley.But as a mum myself, I think it’s heartwarming a teenage boy should be so happy to emulate his mother.OH the utter folly of the face tattoo!The latest to succumb to this trend, which a few years ago would be, frankly, unthinkable, is Amber Rose.She has had the words Bash and Slash tattooed across her forehead in old English manuscript style.It’s a reference, apparently, to the model’s three-month-old son Slash, and six-year-old son Sebastian. And, obviously, it’s lovely that she loves her children so much.But tattooing their names on her forehead where they will remain for all her le  All I can say is: Tattoo in haste . . . repent at leisure.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan and harry by all means demean yourselves but dont demean our queen
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex owe their global superstar status — and their massive earning potential — to their royal connections.That is the wonderful irony about our runaway royals.Harry and Meghan may despise everything about the royal le — the endless scrutiny, the boring engagements, all those fixed smiles for the peasants when they could be hanging out with Oprah and the Obamas and the Clooneys.We get it. We truly do.But do Harry and Meghan understand and ever admit to themselves that they owe EVERYTHING to their royal connections Without the magic dust that royalty bestows, JP Morgan — one of the world’s richest banks — would never have flown them in a private jet to an exclusive company beano. Don’t tell Greta Thunberg!And without his royal blood, Prince Harry would not be in talks with Goldman Sachs about a future relationship.If they were not British royalty, Meghan would be a B-list actress whom few people had ever heard of and Harry an old soldier with two rotten A-levelsfrom Eton — a school where my dog Stan could get four good grades and an offer from Oxbridge.I do not doubt Harry and Meghan’s sincerity when they say they want to be financially independent.But because they are poncing on royal connections, the couple have a duty of care to the Queen and to this country.Please don’t embarrass the Royal Family, or British people who shelled out £million for your wedding.Please do not turn into the preening glove puppets of investment bankers.Oh Harry, please don’t turn into Tony Blair in a tiara.Oh Meghan, don’t become the st-century Fergie.Prince Andrew’s reckless friendship with convicted billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein has humiliated and damaged the Royal Family.Andrew’s total lack of judgment may have done irreparable harm to the monarchy.Many of us wonderthe institution will last after the Queen has gone.So show some dignity, Harry and Meghan. Engage your brains, not your bank balance.Have a little DISCRETION. Please do not pimp your royal connections to any passing dodgy billionaire or investment banker who claims to care deeply about your charity work.Frankly, it doesn’t look good so far.The nation cringed when Prince Harry buttonholed Disney boss Bob Iger at the London premiere of The Lion King, aggressively pitching Meghan’s availability for “voiceover” work.A member of the Royal Family begging a Hollywood big-shot for work was not a pretty sight.When they handed in their letter of resignation, Harry and Meghan made lofty announcements about “collaborating” with the Queen, as though Her Majesty, , is some grime DJ who could be brought in to remix their latest single.The brutal truth is that we will not see much of Harry and Meghan in these parts.This week they sacked  loyal UK staff and shut their Buckingham Palace office.But by turning their backs on the royal le, Harry and Meghan have placed themselves in an almost impossible situation.They claim to want to be financially independent of Prince Charles and the British taxpayer.Then they will have to grab the big pay days where they can.They will have to earn phenomenal sums of money to fund the lavish lestyle to which they are accustomed.But there is absolutely nothing in either of their CVs to suggest they can make that kind of dough without flogging their royal connections to the highest bidder.If Harry and Meghan are going to support themselves, they are going to have to get their hands dirty in the working world.Harry’s discussions with Goldman Sachs may be focused on his charity work right now, but investment bankers are not renowned for their boundless human compassion.Big bankers — and mega-rich companies like Netflix and Apple — will look at Harry and Meghan and wonder what they can get out of them.Harry and Meghan are free to demean themselves, as Harry did so spectacularly when he shook his diamond-encrusted begging bowl at the boss of Disney.But please don’t demean this country.Please don’t debase the Royal Family, as Prince Andrew has done.Please, Harry and Meghan — do not embarrass the Queen.Because let’s face it, chaps — without your royal connections, the pair of you really don’t add up to very much at all.After all those wild decades, Keith – who is said to have smoked an estimated , fags in his time – clearly believes in moderation in all things.Especially moderation in moderation.IN a pithy turn of phrase worthy of Oscar Wilde, one commentator mused that Labour’s dishevelled Tracy Brabin looked like she had been “banged over a wheelie bin” in her off-the-shoulder frock in the House of Commons.Showing Tracy how it is done, Kate Beckinsale looked stunning in a very similar off-the-shoulder number at a pre-Oscars party.Kate also looks as though she has never even seen a wheelie bin.But it’s not true. I recall Debbie Harry was a dazzling double NME winner in  – Pin-Up Of The Year and Best Female Singer.The NME may be  years old. But NME award winners never get any older.THE coronavirus could well be China’s Chernobyl – the national calamity that changes everything.As the global death toll of the virus nears ,, the old men in Beijing who run China have never looked so woefully out of their depth.The greatest hero in China today is Dr Li Wenliang, the -year-old Wuhan doctor who tried to warn the Communist regime of the virus.Dr Li was arrested, bullied, humiliated, accused of scaremongering and later died of the virus.That is what happens in a one-party state that considers all criticism to be treason.China does not look like the next economic superpower today.China looks like an inept one-party state that failed to grasp the seriousness of the virus, then stubbornly refused to heed the warnings that could have contained it, and has now exported it to the rest of the world.The coronavirus came out of the so-called wet markets of China, where every conceivable animal is kept in filthy conditions to cater for the Chinese appetite for “exotic” animals.Wolf pups, koala bears and assorted rats, bats and snakes are all on offer for the discerning wildle gourmet, many under the counter.These markets were the breeding ground for Sars nearly  years ago, and they were the breeding ground for the coronavirus.Exactly how stupid can a regime be that allows the existence of these unregulated markets  The virus that is now polluting the entire planet was totally avoidable.Mikhail Gorbachev was convinced that the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in  caused the collapse of the Soviet Union five years later.The Chernobyl explosion “opened the possibility of much greater freedom of expression”, said Gorbachev. “To the point that the system as we knew it could no longer continue.”If the coronavirus brings down China’s ruling Communist elite, it will be exactly what they deserve.Now Leo has seen his Fine Gael party poll a wretched . per cent of the vote in the Irish general election, going from power to third place overnight.Looks like Leo Varadkar is a teeny-weeny politician now.Now BBC chairman David Clementi squeaks that ending the licence fee will mean scrapping children’s channel CBeebies.Stop our money and you will make all the kiddies cry!But the openly biased BBC stopped being a state broadcaster years ago.It no longer deserves to be funded like one.TANYA McDonnell is a modern success story.Tanya was working in McDonald’s in Washington, Tyne-and-Wear, for £ an hour until a modelling agency spotted her holiday shots on Instagram.“I’d always looked up to people like Kate Moss,” says Tanya. “But I didn’t think I had a chance because I wasn’t pretty enough.”Only in the age of social media could a girl go from having her picture taken on holiday to making a living as a model.And only in the age of social media could someone who looks like Tanya McDonnell fret that she is not pretty enough.I didn’t know he had one.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL title: banksy valentines day graffiti vandals
story: The Valentines Day-inspired street art, which shows a young girl firing a slingshot of flowers in the artists usual stencil style, has now been defaced with the words BCC W***ERS.The mural was first spotted by locals in Marsh Lane on Thursday and celebrated by all Bristolians alike.But a photo of the vandalised piece has since been shared on social media.The family who own the house n which the artwork appeared have now covered it in an effort to protect it.Kelly Woodruff, the daughter of Edwin Simons, who owns the rented home said: Due to the mindless vandalism to the artwork, the family have taken the very dficult decision to cover the artwork to try to protect it.The family feels a strong responsibility to ensure the art is available for the enjoyment of the people of Bristol and the general public.All measures are temporary and we ask that the public are patient while we work out the best way to clean the damage, restore and protect it for the future so everyone can enjoy Banksys work.We hope everyone will understand that these steps are necessary.One local resident who spotted the vandalism said: Its a real shame, but it was always going to happen, unfortunately.Bristolians were excited about the new work when it first appeared earlier this week.Kelly Woodruff, , whose father owns a house on Marsh Lane, said she was gobsmacked that Banksy had drawn the mural on her dads birthday.She said: Im so excited. Its given everyone a bit of a buzz.I havent even spoken to my dad about it yet. I saw it on Facebook and immediately texted it to him. Its his birthday.The new graffiti is remarkably similar to Banksys iconic Balloon Girl mural.The piece shows a young girl with her hand extended toward a red heart-shaped balloon being carried away by the wind.It was first spotted in  in ious spots in London and has become one of Banksys most famous works.Banksy is an elusive graffiti artist whose real identity has never been revealed.His street art has been spotted around the south of England, including London, Brighton and Bristol as well as prominent international locations.He is one of the worlds richest and best known artists worth an estimated £million.But last year, his ex-agent Steven Lazarides released a series of exclusive pictures of the young artist at work.The snaps show the secretive street scribbler working on some of his most famous etchings, but his face still remains a mystery.He has at ious times been rumoured to be Bristol street artist Robin Gunningham and Massive Attack musician Robert Del Naja.

title: caroline flack honesty sunshine our life inspired
story: She was also one of the most honest.Unlike so many of our cosseted household names she was approachable, witty and refreshingly open about her own le and struggles.She spoke with candour about title: brexit points based immigration system
story: This Government promised to get Brexit done and we delivered.But that wasn’t our only promise you overwhelmingly backed at the ballot box.We also promised to deliver a points-based immigration system that delivers for the whole of the United Kingdom and this week we will set out plans do just that.On Friday, the new Cabinet backed mine and the Prime Minister’s vision to take back control of who comes to this country.We agreed a radical, new, firm but fair system that rewards the skills people have to offer, not where they come from.Sun on Sunday readers have been with us on this journey.And I can make another promise, that you will finally have an immigration system that works in the interests of our country.For too long firms have relied on cheap, foreign low-skilled labour rather than investing in our workers.They have exploited free movement to undercut you, taking away jobs and driving down wages.For too long we were powerless to help, shackled by Europe and forced to be rule-takers. Ending free movement changes all that.The Government has listened to the clear message from the  referendum and the  General Election that the public wants a reduction in low-skilled immigration.We want to see overall numbers down and this new system will deliver. Our new immigration system will turn off the tap of cheap, foreign low-skilled labour.Workers coming to the UK will have to prove they have something to offer.We are not closing our doors, but we will finally be able to choose who comes through them.We will attract the top talent from anywhere in the world.Allowing us to attract the brightest and the best from around the globe who will help our economy to thrive.From next year, all skilled workers will need to earn enough points to work in the UK.They will need to speak English, have a firm job offer, and meet the salary requirements.Extra points will be awarded to people who have the most to offer, including those working in a profession where there is a real skills shortage.We will continue to monitor – through expert advisers –there are shortages and gaps to be filled.For those coming to work in our NHS and schools, points will be awarded in line with pay scales for their professions.This is only the beginning, and this week we will set out our plans to go even further with a system to deliver the reforms you want.For the first time in decades, the UK will have control over who comes to our great country and how our immigration system works.We’ve got Brexit done, now we’re moving on to focus on the people’s other priorities.We promised to unleash our country’s full potential and we are doing just that. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: drinkers brave storm dennis dublin pedal bar
story: Hilarious video footage captured the group of tourists pedalling furiously against the ,-mile wide Dennis the Menace storm’s mph gusts and mm of rain.Amused passers-by watched on as the open-sided bus spectacle travelled through the Irish capital.One onlooker said: “It looked like they were doing their best to finish the tour as soon as possible and get to the nearest pub.”The Dublin Pedal Tours website says that riders are provided with “ponchos for what rain the roof doesn’t keep away.”They hire out the buses - which come with a u-shaped bar and can carry up to eight people - to tourists including hen and stag dos and work colleagues on team building excursions.It was clear from the video footage that the drinkers weren’t going to let the grim forecast, lashing winds and limited weather protection stop them from completing the drinking tour.The footage was posted on Twitter where one commenter joked: “Thats their morning after transport to the airport, clears the head before getting home.”It comes as the UK faces a second weekend of brutal weather with Storm Dennis.The wild weather is predicted to be worse than last weeks Storm Ciara - dubbed the storm of the century - due to heavy rain hammering down on already saturated ground.Two lives have been claimed by the mph bomb cyclone, as the army was deployed to help with flood relief.Severe weather warnings are in place for much of the country and forecasters say the perfect storm could bring a months rainfall in some places.The Environment Agency says there are  flood warnings in place and  flood alerts across the UK.Several rivers have already burst their banks, causing flooding across the country.Travel chaos is expected and flights cancelled amid eight weather warnings.More than  EasyJet flights in and out of the UK on Saturday have been axed due to the danger to le warnings - ruining , passengers half-term and holiday plans.Network Rail advised passengers to expect disruption on many routes due to flooding and to allow more time for their journeys.The storm is also likely to cause treacherous driving conditions.A bomb cyclone, or explosive cyclogenesis, is caused by a sharp drop in air pressure within a storm.This can create winds of up to mph.It happens when the air pressure drops by  millibars within  hours, which shts the weather dramatically.It got the name due to the dramatic drop which is similar to a bomb exploding.Met Office meteorologist Greg Dewhurst said: On a slightly more technical definition, its called rapid cyclogenesis. Its a low pressure system which drops  milibars in  hours or more.An easier way to think of it is, its a low pressure weather system that drops really quickly.

story: One player accounts for the bulk of the tally, with their EuroMillions ticket from December worth more than £million.Dorset - which is the second richest county in the UK for property wealth - has three jackpot winners who have failed to come forward to claim a staggering £,,.The mystery punter who won £,,.p on the EuroMillions in December has still not come forward to claim the massive prize and now has until the end of May this year to claim it - or lose the lot to the good causes fund.But there is another Dorset ticket holder who won £,,.p in a EuroMillions draw in October.They only have until April st to claim it, or again lose it all. title: paisley mum slept in bathtub for seven months to hide from her stalker ex
story: Joanne McGonigle, , barricaded herself in the loo and lay in the dark fearing James McPhillips, , would break into her flat and kill her.Her desperate bid to evade the creep came after he bombarded her with thousands of sinister messages following their split.He told her: “You’re gonna suffer — I promise you.”Speaking after McPhillips was convicted over his terrying hate campaign, Joanne, of Paisley, near Glasgow, said: “I would wake up every morning in the bathtub. I felt safer in there as there are no windows. I was frightened that he would get in and kill me.“I’d lie down and turn the lights out — I prayed he would leave me alonehe thought I wasn’t there.”Joanne and McPhillips were together for  years before she kicked him out of their home in the town.She said he had become “distant” and “secretive” and would regularly fly off the handle for any reason.McPhillips moved in with a friend but soon began harassing her with vile texts and voicemails — sending hundreds of threats daily.In one sickening message, the cruel bully pretended to be her stillborn daughter.Joanne said of the texts: “They would start first thing in the morning and go on until last thing at night. He would say he was my wee girl and that I let her die — that I deserved the fact she is gone.“He threatened to cut my throat and blow up my car. He’d throw things at the windows and look through the letterbox. I was terried he would take my kids.”She added: “My own home was like a prison. The lights and TV were never on. I thought he would kill me.” Joanne said he told her he’d “put a price” on her head.She continued: “He told me to watch my back when I left home as he had paid somebody to do me in. I was looking over my shoulder everywhere I went.“He’d text saying he was outside and he was going to smash my windows in.”McPhillips, of Darvel, Ayrshire, started his five-month campaign shortly after the couple split in October .Joanne called cops and he was banned from Paisley.But she had to continue hiding in her bathroom — as he ignored the order and was discovered in her street.McPhillips was eventually charged and last week the coward pleaded guilty at Paisley Sherf Court to making repeated threats.He was also accused of chasing Joanne along a pavement on a motorbike, but prosecutors dropped the allegation.Joanne added: We’d been together for a long time but that meant nothing in the end. They need to lock him up — he is dangerous. I dread to think what he could do to somebody .”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: w.mantis  How DWPs five-week wait for Universal Credit has cost thousands where you live n EXCLUSIVE: The five-week wait for Universal Credit is making thousands turn to advance payments - but they have to be paid back out of your own benefits. These figures show advance repayments cost £m in one month alone - with struggling northern English towns the worst hit n Nearly £million of  Universal Credit benefit payments were clawed back from the poorest households in one month last year, according to the Tory government’s own figures.  nNew claimants for Universal Credit have to wait a minimum of five weeks for their first payment to be processed, forcing many to take out loans form from the Government.  nThe borrowing, known as Advance Payments, to cover their basic living costs before their first entitlement arrives and is then deducted from regular payments.  nThe delay has faced harsh criticism with MPs warning that the need to borrow forces claimants into a cycle of debt with some ending up at food banks as a result. nThe Department for Work and Pensionsadmitted that in August , the latest period available, it deducted £ million from claimants across the UK to pay back their loans.  nThe ten worst hit areas are in northern towns in what has been referred to as the Red Wall - traditional Labour seats in the North and Midlands many of which fell to the Tories for the first time in the December election. nKnowsley was the worst hit with £, repaid for UC Advance Repayment deductions during August closely followed by Hartlepool on £, and Bootle with £,. n  n   nBoris Johnsonaposs Mustique villa stay mystery deepens as owner speaks out  n Woman jobless since  dreams of aposselling jamapos and applied for  jobs in a day   nIn Glasgow South West, the constituency of Chris Stephens MP who asked for the figures, £, was repaid for UC Advance Repayment deductions in one month.  nStephens described the figures showing the money being clawed back from some of the most deprived areas of the country as “astonishing”  nIt is clear from this answer that the DWP Advance Payment system simply doesn’t work and demonstrates that the UK Social Security system is broken.”  nStephens said: “I would urge all Parliamentary colleagues to look at these figures and to press the UK Government to build a social security system fit for purpose, starting with ending the five week wait.”  n“What is required is to end the five week wait, and introduce a first payment within the first two weeks of a claim without the need to pay this back – the current system is a vicious circle of debt.”  n  n   n Cabinet approves post-Brexit points-based system to cut low-skilled migrants   nA DWP spokesperson said: “In August  alone £.bn in Universal Credit was paid out across the UK, and advance repayments amounted to less than  percent of that figure.”  nIn full: The  UK areas worst-hit by Universal Credit advances  n nKEY: Constituency and how much was repaid in Universal Credit advances in August  alone. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNearly £million of  Universal Credit benefit payments were clawed back from the poorest households in one month last year, according to the Tory government’s own figures. New claimants for Universal Credit have to wait a minimum of five weeks for their first payment to be processed, forcing many to take out loans form from the Government. The borrowing, known as Advance Payments, to cover their basic living costs before their first entitlement arrives and is then deducted from regular payments. The delay has faced harsh criticism with MPs warning that the need to borrow forces claimants into a cycle of debt with some ending up at food banks as a result.The Department for Work and Pensionsadmitted that in August , the latest period available, it deducted £ million from claimants across the UK to pay back their loans. The ten worst hit areas are in northern towns in what has been referred to as the Red Wall - traditional Labour seats in the North and Midlands many of which fell to the Tories for the first time in the December election.Knowsley was the worst hit with £, repaid for UC Advance Repayment deductions during August closely followed by Hartlepool on £, and Bootle with £,.In Glasgow South West, the constituency of Chris Stephens MP who asked for the figures, £, was repaid for UC Advance Repayment deductions in one month. Stephens described the figures showing the money being clawed back from some of the most deprived areas of the country as “astonishing” It is clear from this answer that the DWP Advance Payment system simply doesn’t work and demonstrates that the UK Social Security system is broken.” Stephens said: “I would urge all Parliamentary colleagues to look at these figures and to press the UK Government to build a social security system fit for purpose, starting with ending the five week wait.”  “What is required is to end the five week wait, and introduce a first payment within the first two weeks of a claim without the need to pay this back – the current system is a vicious circle of debt.”  A DWP spokesperson said: “In August  alone £.bn in Universal Credit was paid out across the UK, and advance repayments amounted to less than  percent of that figure.” In full: The  UK areas worst-hit by Universal Credit advances KEY: Constituency and how much was repaid in Universal Credit advances in August  alone. Other deductions were taken for other reasons - such as overpayments, arrears, fines or fraud - but advance payment deductions made up £.million of the £.million in total deductions across the country. . Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge knows the importance of early years development in children, and the back-up that young parents need. She knows getting this wrong at the ­beginning makes for unhappy endings in teenage years and adulthood. She knows that one of the main causes of death in young mums is suicide, which is why she is building a support network to help them. Kate also knows that no matter where you come from, children and parents need support. But background determines whether that support will be forthcoming. Which is why the Tory attack on Sure Start centres is all the more shocking. Today we reveal how austerity cuts mean , have shut since  – that’s more than one in three. Yet Sure Starts do everything that Kate is talking about and more. They not only provide clinics, health advice and support for parents but can identy abuse and neglect early. Now , fewer children have such protection, and that is a national scandal. Better to prevent a child being abused in the first place than wring our hands in horror after the event. Better to spot a young mother’s depression and treat it than to weep at her graveside. Better that Sure Starts catch ­problems early than for them to fester and cost the NHS an extra £million a year. Sure Starts have proved their worth since being introduced in . Now it’s time for Boris Johnson to recognise their value too. Healthy attitude If there is one thing the three Labour leadership contenders can agree on, it is that the NHS needs to be protected from Tory threats to its existence.  Sir Keir Starmer tells the Sunday Mirror today of his own painful experiences sitting by the bedside of his mother and more recently his mother-in-law.Although he sadly lost them both, he has nothing but praise for the NHS care thatthey received.And it has made him all the more determined to ensure the health service gets the resources it needs. It was the post-war Labour government which introduced the NHS. It was successive Labour governments which looked after it.

Seven-year-old Leah had le-changing surgery to remove the tumour which had grown around her spine and key blood vessels in August last year.Parents Stephen and Claire Bennett, from St Helens, Liverpool,  were told by other hospitals the operation would be too risky to perform but eventually their daughter was saved by staff at Alder Hey and Royal Liverpool hospitals, reports the Liverpool Echo.Before the six-hour operation a D model was made of the tumour which Stephen held. After the couple were told the operation was successful they broke down into floods of tears. After the success of the six-hour operation, Leah was discharged and home in time for her seventh birthday. She has also been fundraising for the hospital with her sister Phoebe.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA four-year-old girl with Down’s syndrome has defied doctors by becoming a child model – after her mum was told she would never live a normal le.Cara Brown was diagnosed with trisomy  – a genetic disorder caused by the presence of all or part of a third copy of chromosome , the most common form of Downaposs syndrome– hours after she was born.The news came as a complete shock to her parents, Meryn, , and Duncan, , since theyaposd been told at their -week scan that the chances of their baby having Downaposs syndrome were low. When doctors told the couple that their daughter would potentially face a whole list of lelong medical conditions, including heart problems, they were heartbroken. But mum-of-two Meryn, from Chesham, Bucks, said Cara is defying the odds by not just walking and talking but modelling for catalogues and campaigns too. The social researcher said: The way the consultant broke the news to Duncan and I wasn’t good – he didn’t have a good bedside manner. “He told us Cara had Down’s syndrome and then listed all the medical issues she could possibly have, such as heart and bowel problems. None of which she does, luckily. “They present it as a really negative thing and just talk about a lot of medical issues.  “When you’re just presented with a long list of problems that your child is going to have, it’s very scary and a terrying thing to hear. “But Cara’s four-and-a-half now and I wish I could go back in time and tell myself that she would be fine and an amazing little girl. “It’s important that adverts and the media reflect society as it really is, and it’s fantastic Cara is contributing towards a more inclusive picture of society and counteracting negative stereotypes of Down’s syndrome. “She’s done so well and I’m so proud of her.”  Cara is now involved in a campaign, Downright Amazing, to educate midwives and doctors to break the news to parents their child has Down’s syndrome in a sensitive way. The idea to kick start her modelling career came from Meryn’s desire to battle the stereotype of the condition, showing children in a positive light. The precocious youngster had her first shoot at two when a local photographer asked for help building his portfolio and is now a natural in front of the camera.  Since then Cara has bagged an agent and picked up paid work for clothing range Little Green Radicals, as well as starring in Downright Amazingaposs campaigns. Sheaposs even become a celebrity in her local area and Meryn said her girl is recognised daily since she began modelling. Meryn said: “Cara loves seeing the photos of herself and she loves doing it because she just gets to play around in the garden having fun. She’s become really confident. “It’s been lovely to see how everything has come together. “She’ll see a picture of herself in the supermarket and she’ll point it out. She’s always smiling and waving at everyone.  “We were in an ice cream shop once and some children recognized her and it was really nice, she loved it.” The youngster’s condition means she is slower in reaching her milestones than her peers but she is now walking, talking and making friends at nursery as well as modelling for catalogues with her -month-old sister, Jessica, who doesnapost have the condition. But Meryn said she and lawyer husband, Duncan have received criticism for Cara’s slower development from people the family doesn’t even know.  She said: “We were in a car dealership a couple of years ago and a couple pointed at Cara and said she was way too old to be crawling. “They were quite embarrassed when I explained that she had Down’s syndrome.

Mum Lucy Carroll told how she “cried with relief” when their new daughter Renesmee got the all-clear after tests. She and husband Mike had suffered the anguish of seeing son Ollie, nine, and his sister Amelia, six, fall victim to Batten Disease. The genetic neurological disorder has robbed Ollie of his ability to walk, talk, see or eat. Amelia is protected from it for now by a new drug – granted only on compassionate grounds while the family fought a ban on NHS funding for it. The Carrolls have two healthy other sons, Micky,  and Danny, . Lucy, , said: “We always wanted five children but thought we couldn’t have another baby because of this disease. In the end, though, we decided not to let it rule our lives. “It’s lovely to see Renesmee with Ollie and Amelia, who both adore her. There’s sadness too, though, because as she grows it reminds us of everything Ollie’s missing out on.” Last September – in a U-turn by health watchdog Nice – Lucy and Mike, , won their campaign for Batten victims to be given the le-saving drug cerliponase alpha on the NHS.  Every fortnight they take Amelia on a -mile round trip for her treatment at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London.

title: hospices not places people delivered
story: w.mantis  Hospices are not places people are delivered to die - they are full of love n Rachel Clarke is based at Katharine House Hospice in Oxfordshire. She has written a book called A Doctor’s Story of Love and Loss  where she talks about her experiences and the patients she has cared for n Rachel Clarke is a palliative care doctor at Katharine House Hospice in Oxfordshire.  nWhen patients are admitted, many are fearful of death.  nBut Rachel and her colleagues are determined to help them live le to the full before they die.  nIn a second moving extract from her book Dear Le: A Doctor’s Story of Love and Loss, she remembers some of the patients and their stories which will stay with her forever...  nDorothy  nDorothy was admitted to the hospice on a Monday. n“There is no point in spending time with me,” she declared on arrival. “I will be dead on Thursday.”  n“What makes you think that ” I asked, intrigued.  n  naposWe must act now to save our hospices - or children will go without careapos   nHospice doctoraposs heartbreaking description how cancer aposstole her dad bit by bitapos   n nShe gave me the kind of lingering stare a teacher reserves for the classroom dunce, then explained: “Mr Edwards. The senior consultant on the surgical ward told me my bowels had stopped working and I would be dead in six days. That was on Friday. I have three days left.”  nI knew the rudiments of Dorothy’s story. Admitted to AE with acute bowel ­obstruction. Given her age –  – an almost certainly terminal diagnosis. But at no stage was there mention of Thursday.  n“I will concede I do not feel full of death,” Dorothy stated. “I feel full of le. Butyou don’t mind, I would rather be left alone. I have little time left and I would like to read my newspaper.”  nRarely in my career had I been dismissed more magnicently. I hardly dared respond.  n“Based on my medical assessment, I am not at all certain you’ll be dead on Thursday,” I told Dorothy. “If you had more time, is there any way you would like to spend it ”  n  n   n“Were I not to be dead on Thursday, then I would certainly be playing bridge with my local group, as I have done every Thursday for the last two decades. But I can assure you I will be dying instead.”  n“How about this,” I proposed. “We plan for bridge, unless death intervenes ”  n“Young lady, I will humour youit makes you feel useful.”  nA good day, for me, in the hospice, is one in which I feel we have helped someone die with comfort and dignity intact.  nBut infinitely preferable are the days when we have helped a dying patient live – be that basking in a bath filled with insanely priced bubblebath, stroking the family Labrador, saying a rushed but no less momentous “I do” from a wheelchair decked in flowers in the hospice chapel, or watching gold finches gleam in the trees outside.  nIn a ward where every patient has a terminal diagnosis, le, in all its loveliness, goes on.  nOn Thursday morning, the nurses busied themselves with washing, sprucing, plumping and preening. When Dorothy finally emerged, dressed for her bridge trip, she could have been Boudica.  nDesperately thin, her chariot a wheelchair, a pre-emptive dose of morphine in her veins, yet nonetheless sitting ramrod straight with crocodile handbag perched on her lap and an impeccably coordinated green tweed skirt, cashmere cardigan and court shoes.  nFlushed with all the fuss and attention, Dorothy was, for that Thursday only, the queen of our ward – and she knew it. For a moment, our eyes met, and she nodded ­imperceptibly.  nThe next morning, when I arrived at her bedside to hear all about her trip, Dorothy bemoaned her poor form. “I simply wasn’t as sharp as usual,” she lamented.  nI raised an eyebrow. “To be fair, Dorothy, no one  around the table had the excuse that they were dying,” I observed. “Did anyone  seem to mind ”  nA mischievous grin, a twinkle in her eye, and then, finally, I was ­liberated from the dunce’s corner with the words: “Dr Clarke, it was magnicent.”  nA few days later, Dorothy died. Mr Edwards, it turned out, was wrong by only  hours, but in that time, how his patient lived.  n  n   nSimon  nSimon, a former policeman in his sixties, had retired a few months earlier. Shortly afterwards, he noticed a lump in his neck, painless, innocuous and perhaps, he had assumed, related to a recent head cold.  nThe lump continued to grow. Still more curious than concerned – he regularly ran  miles before breakfast – he visited his GP.  nThe speed of his referral to hospital impressed him, innocent of the fact he was on a two-week cancer pathway. The scan became a biopsy, the biopsy a consultant, murmuring cryptically about inoperability, as Simon sat stricken, pinned to his seat, hearing nothing of substance after “cancer”.  nI heard him before I set eyes on him. Specically, I heard the sound of air being sucked into his lungs through an airway severely compressed by a tumour.  nSimon was sitting bolt upright, eyes darting, his shirt ripped off and both hands gripping the bed like his le depended on it.  nBeside him stood a woman in her thirties, distraught and dishevelled, saying, “It’s OK, Dad. Look. Look, the doctor’s here. ­Everything’s going to be OK now.”  nSimon stared up at me, gulping for air. There was no way he could sustain this work of breathing. If, as I suspected, panic had exacerbated his airway obstruction, then I knew how to help.  nThe nurses brought the large dose of ­steroids that would, I hoped, begin to shrink the swelling in Simon’s neck. Next, a tiny dose of a fast-acting sedative, just enough to take the edge off his panic.  nI saw his daughter Sophie was crying. He began to describe living alone with cancer, having been widowed a few years previously. “It’s all been so quick. Too much to take in. Sophie,I’m honest, is my rock, but she has Timmy, her boy, to look after as well.”  n“Don’t be ridiculous, Dad,” Sophie ­interjected, almost angrily. “You know looking after you is no problem. We all love being with you, especially Timmy.”  nI broached the topic of the future. “Look, I’m not stupid,” he exclaimed. “I don’t have one, do I  This is it. I know what’s going on.”  nThere are moments in medicine when what you say next feels as pregnant with risk as a surgeon’s first incision. The right words, used wisely, can bridge the airiest expanse between you and your patient but,misjudged, may blow trust to pieces.  n“Simon, are you the kind of person who likes to discuss everything frankly,” I began, “or do you prefer to take things one day at a time, without speculating about the future ”  n“I already know I’m dying,” he responded. “What  could you possibly tell me ”  n“One of the things I’ve noticed working here, Simon, is how often patients feel unable to ask about the thing they’re most preoccupied with, which is what it’s going to be like when they die – and I wonder whether this is something you’d like to talk about ”  nI saw horror distort Sophie’s face, as though I’d trespassed somewhere no doctor should tread but her father,anything, looked relieved.  n“Go on,” he said cautiously.  n“OK...we tend to see the same patterns in people with cancer who are approaching the end of le. One of the first things many patients notice is losing their strength, their energy. I’m guessing you’re already aware of that ”  nA rueful roll of the eyes.  n“No kidding. I used to run marathons. Can’t even get up the stairs now.” “That loss of energy gradually worsens. You might find you need a nap most days, more than one, probably. Then, one day, you realise you’re sleeping more than you’re awake. It’s not painful or horrible, it’s just immensely frustrating. Patients can find it helps to try and plan in advance a bit, saving up their energy for the things that really matter.”  n“Like Timmy,” Simon ­interrupted. “I like to know when he’s visiting so I can have a sleep beforehand.”  n“I didn’t realise that, Dad,” said Sophie.  n“Well, I want to give him my best, don’t I  And I don’t want to lose a second with him.”  nSophie turned to me. “Timmy’s dad’s not around anymore, you see. Left when he was two. Only shows up around Christmas and birthdays. Dad’s more like his real father.”  n“I see,” I said slowly, computing the layers of loss. I went on. “Often, at the end, there aren’t any dramatic changes. That ­sleepiness continues. A patient finds they are sleeping nearly all of the time.  n“You stop feeling hungry and you don’t want to eat. You may stop feeling thirsty too. Then, one day, rather than sleeping, you slip into unconsciousness.  n“It’s not a distinction you are even aware of. Your brain is just more deeply unresponsive. Sometimes, I wonderthis is the body’s way of protecting the mind – you stop being afraid, you’re oblivious to it all.”  nSimon and Sophie were quietly crying.  n“How long do you think I have left ” he asked me directly.  n“I have no reason to think you are going to die today, Simon. I do think your time is short – weeks, not months, perhaps only very short weeks – but I would love to believe we can get you home for a bit,that’s what you would like.”  nSimon said nothing. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailRachel Clarke is a palliative care doctor at Katharine House Hospice in Oxfordshire. When patients are admitted, many are fearful of death. But Rachel and her colleagues are determined to help them live le to the full before they die. In a second moving extract from her book Dear Le: A Doctor’s Story of Love and Loss, she remembers some of the patients and their stories which will stay with her forever... Dorothy Dorothy was admitted to the hospice on a Monday. “There is no point in spending time with me,” she declared on arrival. “I will be dead on Thursday.” “What makes you think that ” I asked, intrigued. She gave me the kind of lingering stare a teacher reserves for the classroom dunce, then explained: “Mr Edwards. The senior consultant on the surgical ward told me my bowels had stopped working and I would be dead in six days. That was on Friday. I have three days left.” I knew the rudiments of Dorothy’s story. Admitted to AE with acute bowel ­obstruction. Given her age –  – an almost certainly terminal diagnosis. But at no stage was there mention of Thursday. “I will concede I do not feel full of death,” Dorothy stated. “I feel full of le. Butyou don’t mind, I would rather be left alone. I have little time left and I would like to read my newspaper.” Rarely in my career had I been dismissed more magnicently. I hardly dared respond. “Based on my medical assessment, I am not at all certain you’ll be dead on Thursday,” I told Dorothy. “If you had more time, is there any way you would like to spend it ”  “Were I not to be dead on Thursday, then I would certainly be playing bridge with my local group, as I have done every Thursday for the last two decades. But I can assure you I will be dying instead.” “How about this,” I proposed. “We plan for bridge, unless death intervenes ” “Young lady, I will humour youit makes you feel useful.” A good day, for me, in the hospice, is one in which I feel we have helped someone die with comfort and dignity intact. But infinitely preferable are the days when we have helped a dying patient live – be that basking in a bath filled with insanely priced bubblebath, stroking the family Labrador, saying a rushed but no less momentous “I do” from a wheelchair decked in flowers in the hospice chapel, or watching gold finches gleam in the trees outside. In a ward where every patient has a terminal diagnosis, le, in all its loveliness, goes on. On Thursday morning, the nurses busied themselves with washing, sprucing, plumping and preening. When Dorothy finally emerged, dressed for her bridge trip, she could have been Boudica. Desperately thin, her chariot a wheelchair, a pre-emptive dose of morphine in her veins, yet nonetheless sitting ramrod straight with crocodile handbag perched on her lap and an impeccably coordinated green tweed skirt, cashmere cardigan and court shoes. Flushed with all the fuss and attention, Dorothy was, for that Thursday only, the queen of our ward – and she knew it. For a moment, our eyes met, and she nodded ­imperceptibly.The next morning, when I arrived at her bedside to hear all about her trip, Dorothy bemoaned her poor form. “I simplywasn’t as sharp as usual,” she lamented.I raised an eyebrow. “To be fair, Dorothy, no one  around the table had the excuse that they were dying,” I observed. “Did anyone  seem to mind ” A mischievous grin, a twinkle in her eye, and then, finally, I was ­liberated from the dunce’s corner with the words: “Dr Clarke, it was magnicent.” A few days later, Dorothy died. Mr Edwards, it turned out, was wrong by only  hours, but in that time, how his patient lived.  Simon Simon, a former policeman in his sixties, had retired a few months earlier. Shortly afterwards, he noticed a lump in his neck, painless, innocuous and perhaps, he had assumed, related to a recent head cold. The lump continued to grow. Still more curious than concerned – he regularly ran  miles before breakfast – he visited his GP. The speed of his referral to hospital impressed him, innocent of the fact he was on a two-week cancer pathway. The scan became a biopsy, the biopsy a consultant, murmuring cryptically about inoperability, as Simon sat stricken, pinned to his seat, hearing nothing of substance after “cancer”. I heard him before I set eyes on him. Specically, I heard the sound of air being sucked into his lungs through an airway severely compressed by a tumour. Simon was sitting bolt upright, eyes darting, his shirt ripped off and both hands gripping the bed like his le depended on it. Beside him stood a woman in her thirties, distraught and dishevelled, saying, “It’s OK, Dad. Look. Look, the doctor’s here. ­Everything’s going to be OK now.” Simon stared up at me, gulping for air. There was no way he could sustain this work of breathing. If, as I suspected, panic had exacerbated his airway obstruction, then I knew how to help. The nurses brought the large dose of ­steroids that would, I hoped, begin to shrink the swelling in Simon’s neck. Next, a tiny dose of a fast-acting sedative, just enough to take the edge off his panic. I saw his daughter Sophie was crying. He began to describe living alone with cancer, having been widowed a few years previously. “It’s all been so quick. Too much to take in. Sophie,I’m honest, is my rock, but she has Timmy, her boy, to look after as well.” “Don’t be ridiculous, Dad,” Sophie ­interjected, almost angrily. “You know looking after you is no problem. We all love being with you, especially Timmy.” I broached the topic of the future. “Look, I’m not stupid,” he exclaimed. “I don’t have one, do I  This is it. I know what’s going on.” There are moments in medicine when what you say next feels as pregnant with risk as a surgeon’s first incision. The right words, used wisely, can bridge the airiest expanse between you and your patient but,misjudged, may blow trust to pieces. “Simon, are you the kind of person who likes to discuss everything frankly,” I began, “or do you prefer to take things one day at a time, without speculating about the future ” “I already know I’m dying,” he responded. “What  could you possibly tell me ” “One of the things I’ve noticed working here, Simon, is how often patients feel unable to ask about the thing they’re most preoccupied with, which is what it’s going to be like when they die – and I wonder whether this is something you’d like to talk about ” I saw horror distort Sophie’s face, as though I’d trespassed somewhere no doctor should tread but her father,anything, looked relieved. “Go on,” he said cautiously. “OK...we tend to see the same patterns in people with cancer who are approaching the end of le. One of the first things many patients notice is losing their strength, their energy. I’m guessing you’re already aware of that ” A rueful roll of the eyes. “No kidding. I used to run marathons. Can’t even get up the stairs now.” “That loss of energy gradually worsens. You might find you need a nap most days, more than one, probably. Then, one day, you realise you’re sleeping more than you’re awake. It’s not painful or horrible, it’s just immensely frustrating. Patients can find it helps to try and plan in advance a bit, saving up their energy for the things that really matter.” “Like Timmy,” Simon ­interrupted. “I like to know when he’s visiting so I can have a sleep beforehand.” “I didn’t realise that, Dad,” said Sophie. “Well, I want to give him my best, don’t I  And I don’t want to lose a second with him.” Sophie turned to me. “Timmy’s dad’s not around anymore, you see. Left when he was two. Only shows up around Christmas and birthdays. Dad’s more like his real father.” “I see,” I said slowly, computing the layers of loss. I went on. “Often, at the end, there aren’t any dramatic changes. That ­sleepiness continues. A patient finds they are sleeping nearly all of the time. “You stop feeling hungry and you don’t want to eat. You may stop feeling thirsty too. Then, one day, rather than sleeping, you slip into unconsciousness. “It’s not a distinction you are even aware of. Your brain is just more deeply unresponsive. Sometimes, I wonderthis is the body’s way of protecting the mind – you stop being afraid, you’re oblivious to it all.” Simon and Sophie were quietly crying. “How long do you think I have left ” he asked me directly. “I have no reason to think you are going to die today, Simon. I do think your time is short – weeks, not months, perhaps only very short weeks – but I would love to believe we can get you home for a bit,that’s what you would like.” Simon said nothing. The silence, though thick with emotion, was not strained. Finally, he raised his eyes and smiled. “OK. I will. Maybe I’ll get to my boy’s birthday too. Thank you, Rachel – I mean it.” When people askmy job is depressing, I reply that nothing could be further from the truth. All that is good in human nature – courage, compassion, our capacity to love – is here in its most distilled form.

Parents Bryn and Leigh Davies and their four children were living in a bungalow at a school where he once worked as a resident caretaker. But they claim they were thrown out by Hertfordshire County Council and given just an hour to pack a few essentials to take to a hotel where they were crammed into two rooms. Through tears, Mrs Davies, , said they are distressed and worried about their future, adding: We have nothing. We were a happy family and we’ve been robbed. I can’t sit back and do nothing. I have four children. I have to fight for them. The Davies and their two sons - Rhys, , and George,  - are now staying in two small rooms in a converted office block  minutes from home. Their daughters - Grace, , and Emily,  - are staying where. Stay-at-home mum Mrs Davies toldthat the family moved into the three-bedroom bungalow at the now-defunct Sheredes Senior School in Hoddesdon, Herts, in January  when her husband was hired.  She said they paid £. a month in subsidised rent, were responsible for bills and maintenance, and carried out modications to accommodate Mr Daviesapos disability from severe back pain. But in July  Mr Davies, , was sacked by the school - unfairly, he claims - and the family were ordered to move out, with the council saying his right to remain in the property automatically ceased in accordance with his Service Occupancy Agreement. The family refused to leave and this led to a y legal battle that made its way to the High Court in October  and Supreme Court in . At the High Court, the Davies argued that they should be allowed to stay in the home and the council had failed to consider the welfare of their children, who were raised in the bungalow.  But the court sided with the council, saying the familyaposs right to occupy the home ended with his job and they had been trespassing ever since he was dismissed. It allowed the council to move ahead with the eviction, but remained in the bungalow, located next to the school gates, and continued to pay rent. The Davies claim they werenapost notied when the council applied for permission to enforce the writ of possession and the case went to court without their knowledge last year, meaning they werenapost giving an opportunity to mount a challenge. Mrs Davies claims the family had no idea they were being evicted until enforcement officers knocked on her door on February .  The council said since the summer of  it had asked the family a number of times to leave voluntarily, but Mr Davies refused. It said it held off from evicting the family for two years while Mr Davies appealed, and the appeals ended last summer. The eviction was authorised by the court, but the Davies claim it was unlawful because they werenapost give notice. They have launched a new challenge, arguing they were deprived of their legal right to seek a stay, and a hearing is due to take place on March . Mrs Davies, whose family have launched an online petition to publicise their case, said tearfully: There was a knock at the door and there were seven enforcement officers there to evict us.  They saidwe did not go we would be arrested and face  weeks in prison. At the end of the day, there were  enforcement officers. At that point, we had to just go.  She added: We were illegally evicted. We were never served a notice.  The whole family has been split up. We’ve been told that the bungalow is to be sold. It’s all for profit, it is greed. The council said it has not yet made a formal decision on the future of the property. Mr Davies now works as a pest control supervisor in London. He claims it was brought on by bullying and harassment in the workplace. Mrs Davies said he was sacked when he was on sick leave. Sheredes School closed in  - a year after Mr Davies was dismissed - and a new academy has since opened in its place. The council doesnapost run the school, but it still owns the bungalow at the site. After being forced out of the home, the family were put in two rooms in a hotel in Great Dumlow, Essex, and then moved into a former office block in Harlow. Mrs Davies said: The most distressing thing is Iaposm not with all of my children. Thereaposs no room for all of us.  We have two studio rooms with two single beds in each but they are not next door to each other. In my room there thereaposs a wardrobe with no hanging rail, a microwave, a washing machine and dryer, a fridge, a two-wing hob and a tiny bathroom. We have nothing to do. We have no TV. Just four weeks ago the Duke and Duchess of Sussex were ­sticking to the official line about ­“iding their time between the UK and Canada”. Because Harry and Meghan have stopped pretending they want to be part-time royals and are ­closing down their Buckingham Palace office. But before they go, some of those axed aides will still have to organise the farewell ­engagements lined up for the Sussexes. title: uks unluckiest bride tells cold
story: w.mantis  UKs unluckiest bride tells of cold feet, cancer and Thomas Cook hell n EXCLUSIVE: Sophie Bohun, , is planning a second wedding after her first was called off following a string of calamities that wrecked her dream big day in Cuba n When Sophie Bohun booked her dream wedding she had no idea of the calamities that lay ahead.  nSophie, , is a contender for Britain’s unluckiest bride after a ­series of traumas which ended with her big day cancelled.  nBut she might have had an inkling things would not go smoothly after fiancé Matt Stevens chickened out from his proposal – twice.  nMatt, , first planned to pop the question at the top of a volcano in Bali at sunrise. But after climbing to the top with the ring in his pocket, his nerves got the better of him.  nNext he took Sophie to a posh London restaurant to do the deed and backed out again – because he thought the scene was too busy.  nEventually he asked Sophie one morning in bed and they began ­planning a beach wedding in Cuba for  guests for October  last year.  nBut six weeks before the big day, Matt’s mum Elaine, , had a bad fall while doing DIY in her kitchen and developed an infection. She could hardly walk and medics told her she might not be able to fly.  n  n   nThomas Cook travel money card customers told to withdraw money now or lose it   nEx-Thomas Cook flight attendant aposmurdered by stalker who broke into flatapos   nDays later Sophie’s sister Kirsty, , was diagnosed with mouth cancer. Her emergency operation was booked for the week of the wedding.  nSophie and Matt, from Minehead, Somerset, decided to go ahead ­without her despite Kirsty being the chief bridesmaid.  nSophie said: “We were all ­devastated. Kirsty’s health was more important than the wedding but ­everything was already booked so we felt we had to go ahead.  n“Kirsty’s children Bertie, who is four, and seven-year-old Beatrice were meant to be my page boy and flower girl, along with their cousins, but they wouldn’t make it either.  n“I didn’t want my mum Paula to have to choose between Kirsty and me so I told her to stay in England to look after my sister, which meant my dad most likely wouldn’t come out to see me get married either.”  nJust when they thought things couldn’t get any worse, there was a blow four weeks before the ­ceremony when Thomas Cook went bust.  nThe couple had booked a £, wedding package with the firm at the Iberostar hotel in Playa Pilar in Cuba.  n  n   nThomas Cook passenger who drunkenly urinated and vomited in plane seat jailed   nSophie said: “Thomas Cook staff were convinced there was going to be a buyout. Sophie, , is a contender for Britain’s unluckiest bride after a ­series of traumas which ended with her big day cancelled. But she might have had an inkling things would not go smoothly after fiancé Matt Stevens chickened out from his proposal – twice. Matt, , first planned to pop the question at the top of a volcano in Bali at sunrise. But after climbing to the top with the ring in his pocket, his nerves got the better of him. Next he took Sophie to a posh London restaurant to do the deed and backed out again – because he thought the scene was too busy. Eventually he asked Sophie one morning in bed and they began ­planning a beach wedding in Cuba for  guests for October  last year. But six weeks before the big day, Matt’s mum Elaine, , had a bad fall while doing DIY in her kitchen and developed an infection. She could hardly walk and medics told her she might not be able to fly. Days later Sophie’s sister Kirsty, , was diagnosed with mouth cancer. Her emergency operation was booked for the week of the wedding. Sophie and Matt, from Minehead, Somerset, decided to go ahead ­without her despite Kirsty being the chief bridesmaid. Sophie said: “We were all ­devastated. Kirsty’s health was more important than the wedding but ­everything was already booked so we felt we had to go ahead. “Kirsty’s children Bertie, who is four, and seven-year-old Beatrice were meant to be my page boy and flower girl, along with their cousins, but they wouldn’t make it either. “I didn’t want my mum Paula to have to choose between Kirsty and me so I told her to stay in England to look after my sister, which meant my dad most likely wouldn’t come out to see me get married either.” Just when they thought things couldn’t get any worse, there was a blow four weeks before the ­ceremony when Thomas Cook went bust. The couple had booked a £, wedding package with the firm at the Iberostar hotel in Playa Pilar in Cuba.  Sophie said: “Thomas Cook staff were convinced there was going to be a buyout. They sent us an email the night before the collapse saying ­everything would be OK. “But then we never heard from anyone again. The staff that we had been dealing with had lost their jobs. “I was already doubting whether we should board the plane because I was worried about my sister, and Matt’s mum was hobbling about with her foot. “In some ways it was a bit of a relief when Thomas Cook folded and we were told the whole thing was ­cancelled but, after everything that happened, we felt numb.” The couple ended up booking a last-minute consolation holiday to Mexico and spent the day they were meant to marry on the beach. Last month they ­finally got back the £, they had paid for their ceremony, hotel and tickets. Their guests, who had booked through Thomas Cook as well, also got their money back because the trip was covered by the Atol financial protection scheme.  Sophie’s sister Kirsty’s operation was a success and she is now almost fully recovered. But the £, the couple spent on gts for their guests was wasted ­because they were etched with last October’s wedding date. Sophie, a personal assistant, said: “We knew Cuba was a long way for our  guests to travel so bought ­everyone jewellery and watches to say thank you. Unfortunately it’s all now sitting upstairs useless. “All the napkins and table ­decorations and stationery had the date on too. So that’s also money wasted. It’s been a nightmare.” The couple, who first got together in  while both working in HR at Debenhams, say planning a new date has left them feeling flat. Sophie said: “It’s hard to get motivated to rearrange everything again.  “We’ve started to throw some ideas around but nobody seems excited about it because they’ve been through all the disappointment with us. We are just disheartened. “My dress is a beautul summer one with little straps so I’d be keen to get married in sunshine. “But I don’t think we will go abroad after our last experience. I don’t want to risk any more bad luck.”

Witnesses were devastated as they watched the fin whale slowly die after being discovered in trouble by a beach clean group who sparked a desperate rescue operation. Steve Green, of Clean Ocean Sailing, told Cornwall Live they had encountered the whale earlier today before seeing it in trouble at the privately-owned Nare Point on the Lizard in Cornwall this afternoon. The British Divers Marine Le Rescuegroup have been called and the public have been asked to stay away from the area. The animal, thought to be ft long, was pronounced dead at about .pm this afternoon after it beached on the rocks. Julia Cable, national coordinator at BDMLR, said the creature is a fin whale, which are also known as finback whale or common rorqual and formerly known as herring whale or razorback whale.
